bestBHT.bht: If Demetrius or anyone else has a complaint against someone, they should bring it before the court, for the law is open and court days are being kept. Let them accuse one another and present their cases in a fair and orderly manner, for there are certain times fixed for the hearing and trying of causes. Tradesmen like Demetrius should not take it upon themselves to judge what is right or wrong. Instead, let the plaintiff bring his accusation and charge, and let the others defend themselves in accordance with the due course of law.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: If Demetrius have a matter... against any man, the law is open."
...the proconsul and his council, as a court of appeal.
Albert Barnes: Have a matter against any man - Have a complaint of injury; if injustice has been done them by anyone.

The law is open - See the margin. Ἀγόραιοι Agoraioi ἄγονται agontai, that is, ἡμέραι hēmerai. There are court-days; days which are open, or appointed for judicial trials, where such matters can be determined in a proper manner.
Let them implead one another - Let them accuse each other in the court. The laws are equal, and impartial justice will be done.
Marvin Vincent: The law is open [αγοραιοι αγονται] Lit., the court - days are being kept."
Deputies [ανθυπατοι] Proconsuls, by whom Asia, as a senatorial province, was governed.
Philip Schaff: If some trade law, some civic regulation, had been infringed, let Demetrius and the others proceed against Paul and his friends.
‘The law is open;’ literally, ‘court days are now going on.’
Let them implead one another.. This is a legal technical phrase in the original Greek, as in the English.
Archibald T. Robertson: Have a matter against any one (εχουσιν προς τινα λογον). For this use of εχω λογον with προς see Matthew 5:32; Colossians 3:13.
The courts are open (αγοραιο αγοντα). Supply ημερα (days), court days are kept, or συνοδο, court-meetings are now going on, Vulgate conventus forenses aguntur.
Let them accuse one another (εγκαλειτωσαν αλληλοις). Present active imperative of εγκαλεω (εν, καλεω), old verb to call in one's case, to bring a charge against, with the dative.
John Gill: The law is open; or court days are kept; there are certain times fixed for the hearing and trying of causes, where and when such an affair should be regularly brought; and not use such disorderly methods, and throw a city into confusion, and break the peace as these men had done.
They are tradesmen, and it does not belong to them, nor should they take upon themselves to judge and determine what is right or wrong.
Let the plaintiff bring his accusation, and charge, and let the others defend themselves, and let things proceed in a due course of law, and so issue.
John Wesley: There are proconsuls — One in every province. There was one at Ephesus.

bhtAttempts.bht: If Demetrius or anyone else has a complaint against someone, they should bring it before the proper legal authorities, for the law is open and the courts are in session. Let them accuse one another and present their case in a fair and orderly manner, for there are certain times appointed for the hearing and trying of causes. It is not for tradesmen like Demetrius to take it upon themselves to judge and determine what is right or wrong. Instead, let the plaintiff bring his accusation, and charge, and let the others defend themselves, and let things proceed in a due course of law. The proconsuls are there to govern and ensure justice in every province, such as in Ephesus.

If Demetrius or anyone else has a complaint, they should bring it before the courts, for the law is open and the court days are being held. Let them accuse one another and present their case in an orderly manner, for there are certain times fixed for the hearing and trying of causes. It is not for tradesmen like Demetrius to judge what is right or wrong. Instead, let them follow the due course of law and allow the proconsuls to govern and ensure justice.

If Demetrius or anyone else has a complaint against someone, they should bring it before the court, for the law is open and court days are being kept. Let them accuse one another and present their cases in a fair and orderly manner, for there are certain times fixed for the hearing and trying of causes. It is not for tradesmen to take it upon themselves to judge what is right or wrong. Instead, let the plaintiff bring his accusation and charge, and let the others defend themselves in accordance with the due course of law.

It is not for tradesmen to take it upon themselves to judge what is right or wrong. Instead, let the plaintiff bring his accusation and charge, and let the others defend themselves in accordance with the due course of law.

If Demetrius or anyone else has a complaint against someone, they should bring it before the court, for the law is open and court days are being kept. Let them accuse one another and present their cases in a fair and orderly manner, for there are certain times fixed for the hearing and trying of causes. Tradesmen like Demetrius should not take it upon themselves to judge what is right or wrong. Instead, let the plaintiff bring his accusation and charge, and let the others defend themselves in accordance with the due course of law.
